unsigned long int cstrConcatMany ( cstr_t  str,
  ... 
)

Concatenate lots of strings.

This function concatenates all the strings given as argument and places the result in the first argument, str. The strings which are to be concatenated have to be of type char*
The last argument must be NULL

Parameters:
str cstr_t instance which will hold the result
... lots of char* to be concatenated. The last one must be NULL!!
Returns:
the new length of str or 0 if the buffer could not be increased

References CSTR_LEN, CSTR_STR, cstrConcatInPlaceChar(), and cstrConcatMany().

Referenced by cstrConcatMany().

const char* cstrGetChar ( cstr_t  str  ) 

Get a pointer to the string.

This function just calls the CSTR_STR() macro, which gives the pointer to the string It returns a const char * because you should only alter the string using the cstr functions

int cstrIsClone ( cstr_t  str1,
cstr_t  str2 
)

cstr instance comparison

This function compares two cstr instances
It returns true if both objects are exactly the same: equal strings and equal buffer size

Parameters:
str1 cstr_t instance
str2 cstr_t instance
Returns:
1 if the objects are equal. 0 otherwise

void cstrResize ( cstr_t  str  ) 

Re-calculate minimum buffer size.

This function re-calculates the minimum buffer size that is needed to keep the current string. If it is less than the currently allocated, the extra memory will be freed
This is the only way to make the buffer smaller. All the other functions will only increase its size when needed

Parameters:
str cstr_t instance to be resized

References CSTR_LEN, CSTR_SIZE, CSTR_STR, cstrResize(), and powerup().

Referenced by cstrResize().

void cstrReverse ( cstr_t  str  ) 

String reverse.

This function reverses the string stored in str. For example, "abc" is changed to "cba".

Parameters:
str cstr_t instance

unsigned long int cstrSize ( cstr_t  str  ) 

Get buffer size.

This function just calls the CSTR_SIZE() macro, which gives the ammount of currently allocated memory. In other words, it returns the length of the biggest string that is possible to store in str

str cstr_t instance

int cstrUpdate ( cstr_t  str,
const char *  s 
)

Store a new string in a cstr instance.

This function stores the string s in the cstr instance
The buffer will not be resized. If needed, it will be increased, but to make smaller (thus freeing some memory) you must call cstrResize()

Parameters:
str cstr_t instance to store a new string
s char array to be stored in str
Returns:
0 or 1 if it fails or succeeds, respectively

References CSTR_LEN, CSTR_SIZE, CSTR_STR, and cstrUpdate().

Referenced by cstrCopy(), cstrImport(), cstrImportN(), cstrInitChar(), cstrUpdate(), and cstrUpdateFormat().

int cstrUpdateFormat ( cstr_t  str,
char *  fmt,
  ... 
)

Store a new string in a cstr instance according to a format.

This function stores a new string in the cstr instance according to a format. The format specifiers are the following:
%s - a C null terminated string
%d - a C int
%A - a cstr_t instance

An example: suppose you want to create the string "select * from t where u='x' and p='y'". Both values x and y are strings. You have one as a cstr_t instance, a1, and the other as a C null terminated string, s1. The following code will do it:

cstrUpdate(str1, "select * from t where u='%A' and p='%s'", a1, s1);

Parameters:
str cstr_t instance to store a new string
fmt the format string
... the remainder arguments, in the same order as they appear in fmt
Returns:
0 or 1 if it fails or succeeds, respectively

References CSTR_LEN, CSTR_STR, cstrConcatInPlace(), cstrConcatInPlaceChar(), cstrUpdate(), and cstrUpdateFormat().

Referenced by cstrUpdateFormat().

void cstrUpper ( cstr_t  str  ) 

Make the string uppercase.

Parameters:
str cstr_t instance

References cstrUpper().

Referenced by cstrUpper().

unsigned long int powerup ( unsigned long int  n  ) 

Get the next power of 2.

This function computes the smallest k, such that k is a power of 2 and k > n
If n is already a power of two, it returns 2*n

Parameters:
n integer (not a power of two)
Returns:
smallest power of 2 greater than n

References powerup().

Referenced by cstrInit2(), cstrResize(), and powerup().
